Title: A FLEXIBLE ASYNCHRONOUS AC LINK (FASAL) SYSTEM
Address: DEPARTMENT OF ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING, ALIGARH MUSLIM UNIVERSITY, ALIGARH-202002, UP, INDIA  2)IMDADULLAH
Abstract: In the present invention a new flexible ac power transmission link technology has been developed for two asynchronous independent power systems. The flexible asynchronous ac link system abbreviated as FASAL system is a freely rotating rotating-transformer based power transmission or tie line system. It is a doubly fed freely rotating rotating- transformer which is realised by a free-running wound rotor induction machine. It is put in tie line which is in between two separate power systems. It controls the power transfer between these power systems which are asynchronous under some or all operating conditions. In this scheme the power flow is controlled by varying the frequency and / or voltage. Both power systems are here magnetically linked and electrically isolated. In case of a fault on either side of tie line or FASAL system, the effect of fault remains localized being electrically isolated due to magnetic coupling only. Thus it does not drain large power towards fault location or fault side from the healthy power system. Therefore, at the fault condition it gives sufficient cution period for switch-gear to act and isolate the faulty power system. Hence, it prevents the collapse of even a heavily loaded healthy power system or grid.

Title: A VARIABLE FRICTION DAMPER FOR CONTROLLING VIBRATIONS AND OSCILLATIONS OF HYDRAULIC GATES
Address: 2/B, BUTY PLOTS, DHARAMPETH, NAGPUR 440 010, MAHARASHTRA, INDIA.
Abstract: This invention relates to a device for controlling flow induced vibrations & oscillations of different types of hydraulic gates like vertical lift gates, radial gates & tilting type gates used on spillways of dams, canals & barrages. The magnitude of disturbing forces caused by eddies or turbulent flow near the gate depends on extent of opening of gate. Thus, the magnitude of damping force or moment needed to control the vibrations also changes during gate operation. The friction dampers being employed presently provide a constant frictional damping force. The present invention overcomes this drawback by providing variable frictional damping force (in case of linear motion) or variable frictional damping moment (in case of angular motion), as the gate moves from one position to another as the gate travels from fully pen to closed position & vice versa. The device consists of 3 parts - i) a friction track of variable thickness which is fixed to gate, ii) a hinged joint arrangement attached to the gate supporting structure and iii) a friction shoe assembly, which is connected to hinged joint arrangement at one end, and impresses upon the friction track at other end. The friction shoe assembly consists of a self aligning type friction shoe held in a housing with a set of disc springs with a set pre-compression. An inward movement of shoe in the housing causes further compression of the disc springs, resulting in increase in reactive force exerted by springs on the shoe and vice - versa. During operation, when the gate starts to move from open to closed position or vice-versa, the friction shoe assembly swivels or rotates about the pin of hinged joint arrangement, and the self aligning friction shoe presses tightly against the friction track, developing initial frictional resistance. As the gate moves further, a gradually increasing thickness of friction track causes inward movement of shoe in the housing, resulting in development of greater contact force between shoe and track and hence greater frictional resistance. On the other hand, a gradually decreasing thickness of friction track during gate movement results in reduction in frictional resistance developed by the damper. Depending upon the pattern of variation in thickness of friction track, the damper thus develops progressively increasing or reducing frictional resistance or damping force, during movement of gate from one position to another during course of its operation. The novelty of the invention thus lies in typical arrangement comprising of a straight or curved friction track of variable thickness fitted to gate and a self aligning type friction shoe fitted to gate supporting structure and tightly adhering to the friction track, to provide variable frictional damping resistance of various patterns, as the gate moves from one position to another during its travel from fully open to closed position & vice versa. Second novelty of invention lies in use of hinged joint arrangement, which causes swiveling action of friction shoe assembly as soon as the gate starts its movement, and ensures development of initial fixed frictional resistance. Third novelty of the invention lies in use of disc springs and knee type joint between friction shoe & shoe support plate, which enables friction shoe to tightly press on to friction track and provide necessary frictional resistance, while continuously aligning its contact surface with surface of friction track by swiveling in the knee joint, when there is relative motion between the two.

Abstract: Disclosed are techniques for determining a path maximum transmission unit (MTU) of a communication path connecting two or more nodes of a network. This results in the generation and transmission of an MTU error message back to the initiating node. Title: LOADING ESTIMATION USING SCHEDULED UPLINK POWER
Address: SE-164 83 STOCKHOLM (SE) Sweden
Abstract: A method for providing load reference data in a CDMA system comprises measuring of received total wideband power and of received scheduled enhanced uplink power. State variables are selected corresponding to cell power quantities and measurement functions are selected corresponding to the measured received total wideband power and the measured received scheduled enhanced uplink power. A probability distribution for a first power quantity - related to the selected state variables - is estimated. A conditional probability distribution of a noise floor measure is computed based on the estimated probability distribution for the first power quantity. Load reference data is provided based on the computed conditional probability distribution of the noise floor measure. In a preferred embodiment, the first power quantity is a measure of the difference between received total wideband power and received scheduled enhanced uplink power. The load reference data can be used in e.g. enhanced uplink scheduling or admission control.
